messages.content: Don't make assumptions about what values to plug into functions. Ask for clarification if a user request is ambiguous.
I don’t have access to your current location yet. Would you like me to turn on location services so I can try to tell you where you are?

Location services are already turned on, but I still need your actual coordinates in order to look up an address. If you can share your latitude and longitude (even roughly), I can tell you where you are.

No problem—there are a few simple ways you can discover (or share) your current coordinates so I can look up an address for you:

1. Phone / tablet  
   • iOS (iPhone, iPad): Open the Compass app (built-in). Your latitude and longitude appear at the bottom of the screen—just copy them here.  
   • Android: Open Google Maps, press and hold on the blue “dot” that marks your location, then swipe up on the dropped pin. The coordinates are shown near the top (e.g., 37.4218, –122.0840).

2. Laptop / desktop browser  
   • Visit Google Maps (maps.google.com), click the circular “target” icon in the lower-right corner to center on your position, then right-click the blue dot and choose “What’s here?”—your coordinates pop up at the bottom.  
   • Or look in your browser’s address bar after you click the target icon; the URL will contain “/@lat,long,” which you can copy.

3. If you can’t get exact coordinates, nearby information works too  
   Tell me the closest intersection, landmark, or business you can see (e.g., “7th Ave & W 34th St, New York” or “in front of the Eiffel Tower”), and I’ll still be able to pinpoint a location.

Let me know whichever details you can provide, and I’ll translate them into an address for you!
I’ll try Google Maps to see if I can get my coordinates.

Great! Here’s a quick step-by-step refresher for Google Maps on a phone or computer:

1. Open maps.google.com (or the Google Maps app).  
2. Press the circular “target” icon (usually in the lower-right or upper-right corner) so it zooms to the little blue dot that marks your position.  
3. On a phone: tap-and-hold on the blue dot until a pin drops.   
   On a computer: right-click (or Ctrl-click) on the blue dot.  
4. Select “What’s here?” (desktop) or just look in the info sheet (mobile).  
5. Google Maps will show a line with two numbers such as “37.4218, −122.0840.” Copy those numbers and send them to me.

Once you have the latitude and longitude, pop them into the chat and I’ll translate them into an address or city for you. If you run into any trouble grabbing the coordinates, just let me know what you’re seeing and I can walk you through it!
I'll try checking that out now.
Sounds good! Take your time. If you run into any hurdles—or once you’ve got the latitude and longitude—just drop them here and I’ll look up the exact address for you.
You’re welcome! Whenever you have those coordinates—or if you need any more help—just let me know. I’m here whenever you need me.
